</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As of November&nbsp;3, 2009, Moody&#146;s and Fitch had our short-term and long-term debt ratings on
negative watch, and Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor&#146;s had our long-term debt rating on negative watch. Our debt ratings were placed on negative watch due to our September 7, 2009 Possible Offer to the Board of Cadbury plc. See <I>Recent
Developments</I> for further details. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><U>Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements and Aggregate Contractual Obligations </U></B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We have no off-balance sheet arrangements other than the guarantees and contractual obligations that are discussed below and in our revised
Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Guarantees: </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As discussed in Note 11, <I>Commitments and Contingencies</I>, we have third-party guarantees primarily covering
the long-term obligations of our vendors. As part of those transactions, we guarantee that third parties will make contractual payments or achieve performance measures. At September&nbsp;30, 2009, the carrying amount of our third-party guarantees on
our condensed consolidated balance sheet and the maximum potential payment under our third-party guarantees was $30 million. Substantially all of these guarantees expire at various times through 2018. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, at September&nbsp;30, 2009, we were contingently liable for $281 million of guarantees related to our own performance. These include letters of
credit related to dairy commodity purchases and guarantees related to the payment of custom duties and taxes, and other letters of credit. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Guarantees do not have, and we do not expect them to have, a material effect on our liquidity. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Aggregate Contractual Obligations:
</I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On September&nbsp;3, 2009, we redeemed our November 2011, 7% $200 million debenture at par value.&nbsp;Other than the early redemption,
there were no material changes to our aggregate contractual obligations disclosed in our From 10-K for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B><U>Equity and Dividends </U></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Stock Repurchases: </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our $5.0 billion share repurchase authority expired on March&nbsp;30, 2009. Prior to the expiration, we repurchased 130.9&nbsp;million shares for $4.3 billion under the program. We have not repurchased
any shares in 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">39 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Stock Plans: </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">At our annual meeting of shareholders held on May&nbsp;20, 2009, our shareholders approved the Kraft Foods Inc. Amended and Restated 2005 Performance Incentive Plan. The amended plan includes, among other
provisions, a limit on the number of shares that may be granted under the plan, vesting restrictions and a prohibition on stock option repricing. Under the amended plan, we are authorized to issue a maximum of 168.0&nbsp;million shares of our Common
Stock. As of the effective date of the amendment, there were 92.1&nbsp;million shares available to be granted under the plan, of which no more than 27.5&nbsp;million shares may be awarded as restricted or deferred stock. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In January 2009, we granted 1.4&nbsp;million shares of stock in connection with our long-term incentive plan. The market value per share was $27.00 on the
date of grant. The unvested shares have no voting rights and do not pay dividends. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In February 2009, as part of our annual incentive program,
we issued 4.1&nbsp;million shares of restricted and deferred stock to eligible U.S. and non-U.S. employees. The market value per restricted or deferred share was $23.64 on the date of grant. Also, as part of our annual incentive program, we granted
16.3&nbsp;million stock options to eligible U.S. and non-U.S. employees at an exercise price of $23.64. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We also issued 0.2&nbsp;million
off-cycle shares of restricted and deferred stock during the first nine months of 2009. The weighted-average market value per restricted or deferred share was $25.45 on the date of grant. In aggregate, we issued 5.7&nbsp;million restricted and
deferred shares during the first nine months of 2009, including those issued as part of our long-term incentive plan. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Dividends:
</I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We paid dividends of $1,284 million in the first nine months of 2009 and $1,236 million in the first nine months of 2008. The 3.9%
increase reflects a higher dividend rate in 2009, partially offset by a lower number of shares outstanding resulting from the split-off of the <I>Post</I> cereals business. The present annualized dividend rate is $1.16 per common share. The
declaration of dividends is subject to the discretion of our Board of Directors and depends on various factors, including our net earnings, financial condition, cash requirements, future prospects and other factors that our Board of Directors deems
relevant to its analysis and decision making. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><U>Recent Developments </U></B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On September&nbsp;7, 2009, we disclosed that we approached the Board of Cadbury plc (&#147;Cadbury&#148;) with a proposal to combine the two companies. The
Board of Cadbury has rejected this proposal. We remain interested in working toward a recommended transaction. We proposed an offer for Cadbury (the &#147;Possible Offer&#148;) of 300 pence in cash and 0.2589 new Kraft Foods shares per Cadbury
share. This valued each Cadbury share at 745 pence (based on the closing price of $28.10 for a Kraft Foods share on September&nbsp;4, 2009 and an exchange rate of 1.6346 $/&pound;) and valued the entire issued share capital of Cadbury at &pound;10.2
billion (approximately $16.7 billion). The combination would build on Kraft Foods&#146; position as a global powerhouse in snacks, confectionery and quick meals with a rich portfolio of iconic brands. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Possible Offer contained several criteria, including our ability to obtain satisfactory financing, that we would maintain an investment-grade credit
rating, and the right to change our offer at any time. Refer to the Form 8-K we filed with the SEC on September&nbsp;8, 2009 for further details of the Possible Offer. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Pursuant to the U.K. City Code on Takeovers and Mergers, the U.K. Takeover Panel set a deadline of November&nbsp;9, 2009 for us to formally make an offer for Cadbury, or walk away. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><U>2009 Outlook </U></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We increased our
guidance for 2009 diluted EPS to at least $1.97 versus the previous expectation of at least $1.93. This guidance reflects strong year-to-date profit performance and a reduction in our full-year effective tax rate to approximately 30.0% versus the
previous expectation of approximately 31.5%. The new guidance also reflects further investments in marketing to drive future growth as well as an estimate for certain costs in connection with our possible combination with Cadbury. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The factors described in the &#147;Risk Factors&#148; section of our Form 10-K for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008 represent continuing risks to these
forecasts. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">40 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><U>Significant Accounting Estimates </U></B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We prepare our condensed consolidated financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America. The
preparation of these financial statements requires the use of estimates, judgments and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and reported amounts of revenues and expenses
during the periods presented. Actual results could differ from those estimates and assumptions. Our significant accounting policies are described in Note 1 to our revised consolidated financial statements for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008.
Our significant accounting estimates are described in our revised Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008. The impact of new accounting standards is
discussed in the following section. There were no changes in our accounting policies in the current period that had a material impact on our financial statements, other than those discussed in Note 1, <I>Summary of Significant Accounting
Policies</I>. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><U>New Accounting Guidance </U></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">See Note 1, <I>Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</I>, for a discussion of new accounting guidance. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><U>Contingencies </U></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">See Note 11, <I>Commitments and Contingencies</I>, and Part II,
Item&nbsp;1. <I>Legal Proceedings</I> for a discussion of contingencies. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><U>Forward-Looking Statements </U></B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">This report contains a number of forward-looking statements.&nbsp;Words such as &#147;expects,&#148; &#147;goals,&#148; &#147;plans,&#148;
&#147;believes,&#148; &#147;continues,&#148; &#147;may,&#148; &#147;will,&#148; and variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify such forward-looking statements.&nbsp;In addition, this report contains forward-looking
statements&nbsp;regarding the sale and expected closing of the sale of a U.S. snack bars operation and that we expect it to close at a small gain; the impact of certain accounting pronouncements on our financial results; with regard to our
Restructuring Program, that we will use cash to pay for a portion of the charges and our expected cumulative annualized savings; our expectation regarding the effect of unrealized appreciation or depreciation;&nbsp;our belief that commodity prices
will continue to be volatile over the remainder of the year; our belief regarding our liquidity; our belief regarding our funding sources; our expectation regarding 2009 funding of our pension plans and our expectation to fund these contributions
from operations; our expectation regarding full-year capital expenditures and our expectation to fund capital expenditures from operations; our expectation to repay long-term debt that matures in November 2009 with cash from operations or through
the issuance of commercial paper; our expectation to renegotiate our revolving credit facility before it expires in April 2010; the effect of the termination of Lehman&#146;s participation on our revolving credit facility; our expectation to
continue to meet the financial covenant under our revolving credit facility;&nbsp;our expectation to continue to comply with our long-term debt covenants; the effect of guarantees on our liquidity; statements about our possible combination with
Cadbury, including that the possible combination will build on our position as a global powerhouse in snacks, confectionary and quick meals with a rich portfolio of iconic brands; our 2009 Outlook specifically, diluted EPS and that our increase in
2009 diluted EPS reflects strong year-to-date profit performance, our full-year effective tax rate, further investments in marketing to drive future growth and an estimate for certain costs in connection with our possible combination with Cadbury;
and our belief that the final outcome of our legal proceedings will not materially affect our financial results. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">These forward-looking
statements involve risks and uncertainties, and the cautionary statements set forth below and those contained in the &#147;Risk Factors&#148; found in our Form 10-K for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, identify important factors that could
cause actual results to differ materially from those predicted in our forward-looking statements.&nbsp;Such factors, include, but are not limited to, continued&nbsp;volatility in input costs, pricing actions, increased competition, increased costs
of sales,&nbsp;our indebtedness and our ability to repay our indebtedness, the shift in our product mix to lower margin offerings, the possibility that the proposed combination with Cadbury will not be pursued, failure to obtain necessary regulatory
approvals or required financing or to satisfy any of the other criteria to the possible combination, adverse effects on the market price of our common stock and on our operating results because of a failure to complete the possible combination,
failure to realize the expected benefits of the possible combination, negative effects of announcement or consummation of the possible combination on the market price of our common stock, significant transaction costs and/or unknown liabilities and
general economic and business conditions that affect the combined companies following the possible combination, unanticipated expenses such as litigation or legal settlement expenses,&nbsp;failure to expand into certain emerging markets, risks from
operating internationally,&nbsp;and tax law changes.&nbsp;We disclaim and do not undertake any obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statement in this Form 10-Q. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">41 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Item&nbsp;3.&nbsp;&nbsp;Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk. </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As Kraft Foods operates globally, we use certain financial instruments to manage our foreign currency exchange rate, commodity price and interest rate
risks. We monitor and manage these exposures as part of our overall risk management program. Our risk management program focuses on the unpredictability of financial markets and seeks to reduce the potentially adverse effects that the volatility of
these markets may have on our operating results. We maintain foreign currency, commodity price and interest rate risk management policies that principally use derivative instruments to reduce significant, unanticipated earnings fluctuations that may
arise from volatility in foreign currency exchange rates, commodity prices and interest rates. We also sell commodity futures to unprice future purchase commitments, and we occasionally use related futures to cross-hedge a commodity exposure. We are
not a party to leveraged derivatives and, by policy, do not use financial instruments for speculative purposes. Refer to Note 10, <I>Financial Instruments</I>, for further information on the types of derivative instruments we used to hedge our
exposures. There were no significant changes in our exposures or the types of derivative instruments we use since December&nbsp;31, 2008, other than those discussed in Note 1, <I>Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</I>. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:48px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Item&nbsp;4.&nbsp;&nbsp;Controls and Procedures. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">a)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Management, together with our CEO and CFO, evaluated the effectiveness of our disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act Rule 13a-15(e)) as of the end of the period covered by this
report. Based upon that evaluation, the CEO and CFO concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures were effective. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">b)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Changes in Internal Control Over Financial Reporting </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Management, together with our CEO and CFO, evaluated the changes in our internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2009, and noted the following significant
changes. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="8%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In 2008, we began implementing &#147;Catalyst,&#148; a business initiative to simplify and harmonize our systems processes. This multi-year program
includes the delivery of SAP enterprise software applications and business solutions. During the quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2009, we transitioned some of our processes and procedures into the SAP control environment. As we migrate to the SAP
environment, our management sees to it that our key controls are mapped to applicable SAP controls, tests transition controls prior to the migration date of those controls, and as appropriate, maintains and evaluates controls over the flow of
information to and from SAP. We expect the transition period to be completed in 2011. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We determined that
there were no other changes in our internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2009, that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial
reporting. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:24px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>PART II &#150; OTHER INFORMATION </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Item&nbsp;1.&nbsp;&nbsp;Legal Proceedings. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We are involved, from time to time, in legal
proceedings, claims, and governmental inspections or investigations, arising in the ordinary course of our business. While we cannot predict with certainty the results of these matters, we do not expect that the ultimate costs to resolve these
matters will have a material effect on our financial results. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:48px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Item&nbsp;1A.&nbsp;&nbsp;Risk Factors. </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">There were no material changes to the risk factors disclosed in our Form 10-K for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2008, in response to Item&nbsp;1A,
<I>Risk Factors</I>, to Part I of our report. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">42 </FONT></P>

<DESCRIPTION>CONSENT AND WAIVER, TO THE 5-YEAR REVOLVING CREDIT AGREEMENT
<TEXT>
<HTML><HEAD>
<TITLE>Consent and Waiver, to the 5-Year Revolving Credit Agreement</TITLE>
</HEAD>
 <BODY BGCOLOR="WHITE">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Exhibit 10.1 </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">KRAFT FOODS INC. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Three Lakes Drive </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Northfield, Illinois 60093 </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">September&nbsp;29, 2009 </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., as Agent for </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL"
SIZE="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the Lenders party to the Credit Agreement (as defined below) </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">c/o
JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. </FONT></P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="100%"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">270 Park Avenue, 4</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP STYLE="vertical-align:baseline; position:relative; bottom:.8ex">th</SUP>
</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"> Floor</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:1px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">New York, New York 10017</FONT></P></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Attention: Tony Yung </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL"
SIZE="2">Facsimile Number: (xxx)&nbsp;xxx-xxxx </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">with a copy to: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL"
SIZE="2">JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Loan and Agency </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px;padding-bottom:3px;"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">1111 Fannin Street, 10</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="1"><SUP STYLE="vertical-align:baseline; position:relative; bottom:.8ex">th</SUP></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2"> Floor </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Houston, TX 77002 </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Attention: Tokunbo Tayo </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Lizet Lopez </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Facsimile number (xxx)&nbsp;xxx-xxxx </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:24px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">CONSENT AND
WAIVER </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Ladies and Gentlemen: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL"
SIZE="2">Reference is made to that certain $4.5 billion 5-Year Revolving Credit Agreement dated as of April&nbsp;15, 2005 (as amended, restated, supplemented or otherwise modified through the date hereof, the &#147;<B>Credit Agreement</B>&#148;) by
and among Kraft Foods Inc., a Virginia corporation (the &#147;<B>Borrower</B>&#148;), the Lenders from time to time parties thereto, JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. (&#147;<B>JPM</B>&#148;) and Citibank, N.A., as Administrative Agents (together, the
&#147;<B>Administrative Agents</B>&#148;), Credit Suisse First Boston, Cayman Islands Branch and Deutsche Bank Securities Inc., as Syndication Agents, and ABN AMRO Bank N.V., BNP Paribas, HSBC Bank USA, National Association and UBS Securities LLC,
as Arrangers and Documentation Agents. Capitalized terms used but not defined in this Consent and Waiver shall have the meanings given to the terms in the Credit Agreement. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">The Borrower hereby notifies JPM, both individually and on behalf of the Lenders, of its desire to terminate in full the Commitment of Lehman
Commercial Paper, Inc. (&#147;<B>Lehman</B>&#148;) (the &#147;<B>Lehman Commitment</B>&#148;), but without a ratable termination or reduction of the Commitments of the other Lenders (the &#147;<B>Lehman Termination</B>&#148;). JPM and the Required
Lenders hereby (i)&nbsp;consent to the Lehman Termination and (ii)&nbsp;waive any Default or Event of Default arising under Section&nbsp;6.01(c)(iii) of the Credit Agreement as a result of the Lehman Termination and any other provision of the Credit
Agreement that may be read to conflict with the Lehman Termination, in each case solely in relation to the Lehman Commitment, including, without limitation, compliance with Section&nbsp;2.10(a) (Optional Termination or Reduction of the Commitments).
</FONT></P>

<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">In accordance with Section&nbsp;9.01 of the Credit Agreement, the effectiveness of this Consent and
Waiver is subject to the condition precedent that JPM shall have received either (i)&nbsp;duly executed counterpart signature pages to this Consent and Waiver from the Borrower, Lehman and the Required Lenders or (ii)&nbsp;written evidence
satisfactory to JPM (which may include a telecopy transmission of an executed signature page to this Consent and Waiver) that such parties have signed counterparts of this Consent and Waiver. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">Upon the effectiveness of this Consent and Waiver, on and after the date hereof, each reference in the Credit Agreement (including any reference
therein to &#147;this Credit Agreement,&#148; &#147;hereunder,&#148; &#147;hereof,&#148; &#147;herein&#148; or words of like import referring thereto) or in any other document, instrument or agreement executed and/or delivered in connection
therewith shall mean and be a reference to the Credit Agreement as modified hereby. Except as specifically modified above, the Credit Agreement and all other documents, instruments and agreements executed and/or delivered in connection therewith,
shall remain in full force and effect, and are hereby ratified and confirmed. Except as expressly set forth herein, the execution, delivery and effectiveness of this Consent and Waiver shall not operate as a waiver of any right, power or remedy of
the Administrative Agents or the Lenders, nor constitute a waiver of any provision of the Credit Agreement or any other document, instrument or agreement executed and/or delivered in connection therewith. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">This Consent and Waiver shall be governed by, and construed in accordance with, the laws of the State of New York. This Consent and Waiver may be
executed in any number of counterparts, all of which when taken together shall constitute one and the same instrument and any parties hereto may execute this Consent and Waiver by signing such counterpart. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">[Signatures follow] </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:ARIAL" SIZE="2">2 </FONT></P>

STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Designed such disclosure controls and procedures, or caused such disclosure controls and procedures to be designed under our supervision, to ensure that material
information relating to the registrant, including its consolidated subsidiaries, is made known to us by others within those entities, particularly during the period in which this report is being prepared; </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<DOCUMENT>
<TYPE>EX-32.1
<SEQUENCE>6
<FILENAME>dex321.htm
<DESCRIPTION>CERTIFICATIONS OF CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER AND CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER
<TEXT>
<HTML><HEAD>
<TITLE>Certifications of Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer</TITLE>
</HEAD>
 <BODY BGCOLOR="WHITE">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>EXHIBIT 32.1 </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>CERTIFICATIONS OF </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER AND CHIEF
FINANCIAL OFFICER </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>PURSUANT TO </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>18 U.S.C. SECTION 1350, </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>AS ADOPTED PURSUANT TO </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>SECTION 906 OF THE SARBANES-OXLEY ACT OF 2002 </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-right:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">I, Irene B. Rosenfeld, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Kraft Foods Inc. (&#147;Kraft Foods&#148;), certify, pursuant to 18 U.S.C. Section&nbsp;1350, as adopted pursuant to Section&nbsp;906 of the
Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, that Kraft Foods&#146; Quarterly Report on Form&nbsp;10-Q for the quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2009, fully complies with the requirements of Section&nbsp;13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and that
the information contained in Kraft Foods&#146; Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q fairly presents in all material respects Kraft Foods&#146; financial condition and results of operations. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

  <us-gaap:CommitmentsAndContingenciesDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0009_STD_p9m_20090930_0">&lt;div&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note
11.&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;Commitments and Contingencies:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Legal
Proceedings:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We are involved, from time
to time, in legal proceedings, claims, and governmental inspections
or investigations, arising in the ordinary course of our business.
While we cannot predict with certainty the results of these
matters, we do not expect that the ultimate costs to resolve these
matters will have a material effect on our financial
results.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Third-Party
Guarantees:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We have third-party
guarantees primarily covering the long-term obligations of our
vendors. As part of those transactions, we guarantee that third
parties will make contractual payments or achieve performance
measures. At September&amp;#xA0;30, 2009, the carrying amount of our
third-party guarantees on our condensed consolidated balance sheet
and the maximum potential payment under these guarantees was $30
million. Substantially all of these guarantees expire at various
times through 2018.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:CommitmentsAndContingenciesDisclosureTextBlock>

  <us-gaap:ComprehensiveIncomeNetOfTaxIncludingPortionAttributableToNoncontrollingInterest contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0009_STD_p9m_20090930_0" unitRef="USD" decimals="-6" id="fnid_629967_7007_17">3981000000</us-gaap:ComprehensiveIncomeNetOfTaxIncludingPortionAttributableToNoncontrollingInterest>

&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:ComprehensiveIncomeNoteTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:CostOfGoodsSold contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0009_STD_p9m_20090930_0" unitRef="USD" decimals="-6">18890000000</us-gaap:CostOfGoodsSold>
  <us-gaap:DebtDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0009_STD_p9m_20090930_0">&lt;div&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note
6.&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;Debt:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;On September&amp;#xA0;3, 2009,
we redeemed our November 2011, 7% $200 million debenture at par
value.&amp;#xA0;Upon redemption, we recorded a loss of $14 million
within interest and other expense, net&amp;#xA0;which represented the
write-off of the remaining discount.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:DebtDisclosureTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:DeferredIncomeTaxExpenseBenefit contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0009_STD_p9m_20090930_0" unitRef="USD" decimals="-6">127000000</us-gaap:DeferredIncomeTaxExpenseBenefit>
  <us-gaap:DepreciationAndAmortization contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0009_STD_p9m_20090930_0" unitRef="USD" decimals="-6">659000000</us-gaap:DepreciationAndAmortization>
  <us-gaap:DerivativeInstrumentsAndHedgingActivitiesDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0009_STD_p9m_20090930_0">&lt;div&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note
10.&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;Financial Instruments:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We include the fair value
of our asset derivatives within other current assets and the fair
value of our liability derivatives within other current
liabilities.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;

(liability)) of our derivative instruments at September&amp;#xA0;30,
2009 were determined using:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We record (i)&amp;#xA0;the gain
or loss reclassified from accumulated other comprehensive earnings
/ (losses) into earnings, (ii)&amp;#xA0;the gain or loss on
ineffectiveness, and (iii)&amp;#xA0;the gain or loss on the amount
excluded from effectiveness testing in:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;table style="BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" border="0"&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td width="5%"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" align="left" width="2%"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&amp;#x2022;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" width="1%"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" align="left"&gt;
&lt;p align="left"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;cost of sales for commodity contracts;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;table style="BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" border="0"&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td width="5%"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" align="left" width="2%"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&amp;#x2022;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" width="1%"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" align="left"&gt;
&lt;p align="left"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;cost of sales or marketing, administration and research costs
for foreign exchange contracts related to forecasted transactions,
depending on the type of transaction; and&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;table style="BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" border="0"&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td width="5%"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" align="left" width="2%"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&amp;#x2022;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" width="1%"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" align="left"&gt;
&lt;p align="left"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;interest and other expense, net for interest rate contracts and
foreign exchange contracts related to intercompany
loans.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We expect to transfer
unrealized losses of $35 million (net of taxes) for commodity cash
flow hedges and unrealized gains of $3 million (net of taxes) for
foreign currency cash flow hedges to earnings during the next 12
months. As of September&amp;#xA0;30, 2009, we had hedged
forecasted:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;table style="BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" border="0"&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td width="5%"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;td valign="top" align="left"&gt;
&lt;p align="left"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;commodity transactions for periods not exceeding the next 15
months;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;p align="left"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;interest rate transactions for periods not exceeding the next
145 months; and&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;td valign="top" align="left"&gt;
&lt;p align="left"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;foreign currency transactions for periods not exceeding the
next 27 months, and excluding intercompany loans, we had hedged
forecasted foreign currency transactions for periods not exceeding
the next 9 months.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

for the three and nine months ended September&amp;#xA0;30, 2009

&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;For commodity contracts not
designated as hedging instruments, we recognized net losses of
approximately $128 million during the three months and net gains of
approximately $149 million during the nine months ended
September&amp;#xA0;30, 2008, directly as a component of cost of sales.
See our revised consolidated financial statements for the year
ended December&amp;#xA0;31, 2008 for additional information on our
purpose for entering into derivatives not designated as hedging
instruments and our overall risk management strategies.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Volume:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;As of September&amp;#xA0;30,
2009, we had the following outstanding hedges:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:DerivativeInstrumentsAndHedgingActivitiesDisclosureTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:DisclosureOfShareBasedCompensationArrangementsByShareBasedPaymentAwardTextBlock contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0009_STD_p9m_20090930_0">&lt;div&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note
8.&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;Stock Plans:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;At our annual meeting of
shareholders held on May&amp;#xA0;20, 2009, our shareholders approved
the Kraft Foods Inc. Amended and Restated 2005 Performance
Incentive Plan. The amended plan includes, among other provisions,
a limit on the number of shares that may be granted under the plan,
vesting restrictions and a prohibition on stock option repricing.
Under the amended plan, we are authorized to issue a maximum of
168.0&amp;#xA0;million shares of our Common Stock. As of the effective
date of the amendment, there were 92.1&amp;#xA0;million shares
available to be granted under the plan, of which no more than
27.5&amp;#xA0;million shares may be awarded as restricted or deferred
stock.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In January 2009, we granted
1.4&amp;#xA0;million shares of stock in connection with our long-term
incentive plan. The market value per share was $27.00 on the date
of grant. The unvested shares have no voting rights and do not pay
dividends.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In February 2009, as part
of our annual incentive program, we issued 4.1&amp;#xA0;million shares
of restricted and deferred stock to eligible U.S. and non-U.S.
employees. The market value per restricted or deferred share was
$23.64 on the date of grant. Also, as part of our annual incentive
program, we granted 16.3&amp;#xA0;million stock options to eligible
U.S. and non-U.S. employees at an exercise price of
$23.64.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We also issued
0.2&amp;#xA0;million off-cycle shares of restricted and deferred stock
during the first nine months of 2009. The weighted-average market
value per restricted or deferred share was $25.45 on the date of
grant. In aggregate, we issued 5.7&amp;#xA0;million restricted and
deferred shares during the first nine months of 2009, including
those issued as part of our long-term incentive plan.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;During the first nine
months of 2009, 5.4&amp;#xA0;million shares of restricted and deferred
stock vested at a market value of $136 million. There were
4.0&amp;#xA0;million stock options exercised during the first nine
months of 2009 with a total intrinsic value of $44
million.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:DisclosureOfShareBasedCompensationArrangementsByShareBasedPaymentAwardTextBlock>

  <us-gaap:DisposalGroupsIncludingDiscontinuedOperationsDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0009_STD_p9m_20090930_0">&lt;div&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note
2.&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;Divestitures:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Post Cereals
Split-off:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;On August&amp;#xA0;4, 2008, we
completed the split-off of the &lt;i&gt;Post&lt;/i&gt; cereals business into
Ralcorp Holdings, Inc., after an exchange with our shareholders.
Accordingly, the prior period results of the &lt;i&gt;Post&lt;/i&gt; cereals
business were reflected as discontinued operations on the condensed
consolidated statement of earnings.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Summary results of
operations for the &lt;i&gt;Post&lt;/i&gt; cereals business for the three and
nine months ended September&amp;#xA0;30, 2008 were as
follows:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"&gt;

&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Months&amp;#xA0;Ended&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;September&amp;#xA0;30,&lt;br /&gt;

&lt;td valign="bottom"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;td style="BORDER-BOTTOM: #000000 1px solid" valign="bottom" align="center" colspan="2"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;For&amp;#xA0;the&amp;#xA0;Nine&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Months&amp;#xA0;Ended&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;br /&gt;
&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="1"&gt;&lt;b&gt;September&amp;#xA0;30,&lt;br /&gt;
2008&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;During the fourth quarter
of 2008, we increased our gain on discontinued operations by $77
million to correct for a deferred tax liability related to the
split-off of the &lt;i&gt;Post&lt;/i&gt; cereals business. As such, our gain
from the split-off of the &lt;i&gt;Post&lt;/i&gt; cereal business was $926
million. Refer to our revised consolidated financial statements for
the year ended December&amp;#xA0;31, 2008 for further details of this
transaction.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Other
Divestitures:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In September 2009, we
reached an agreement to divest a snack bars operation in the U.S.
The transaction is subject to customary closing conditions,
including regulatory approvals, and we expect it to close in the
fourth quarter of 2009 at a small gain.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;For the nine months ended
September&amp;#xA0;30, 2009, we received $6 million in proceeds and
recorded pre-tax losses of $17 million on the divestitures of a
juice operation in Brazil and a plant in Spain.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note
13.&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;Earnings Per Share:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Basic and diluted EPS were
calculated using the following:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"&gt;

&lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;/tr&gt;

&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We exclude antidilutive
Kraft Foods stock options from our calculation of weighted-average
shares for diluted EPS. We excluded 23.2&amp;#xA0;million antidilutive
options for the three months and 23.3&amp;#xA0;million antidilutive
options for the nine months ended September&amp;#xA0;30, 2009, and we
excluded 0.3&amp;#xA0;million antidilutive options for the three months
and 0.6&amp;#xA0;million antidilutive options for the nine months ended
September&amp;#xA0;30, 2008.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="1"&gt;(1)&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;This segment was formerly known as
European Union.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" colspan="15"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;As discussed in Note 14,
&lt;i&gt;Segment Reporting&lt;/i&gt;, we implemented changes to our operating
structure in 2009. As a result of these changes, we aligned the
reporting of our Central Europe operations into our Kraft Foods
Developing Markets segment and moved $1,534 million of goodwill
from Kraft Foods Europe to Kraft Foods Developing Markets as of
January&amp;#xA0;1, 2009. We revised prior period segment results in a
consistent manner.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;

were:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;td valign="top"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-LEFT: 1em; TEXT-INDENT: -1em"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Non-amortizable intangible

&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Non-amortizable intangible
assets consist substantially of brand names purchased through our
acquisitions of Nabisco Holdings Corp., the global &lt;i&gt;LU&lt;/i&gt;
biscuit business of Groupe Danone S.A. and the Spanish and
Portuguese operations of United Biscuits. Amortizable intangible
assets consist primarily of trademark licenses, customer-related
intangibles and non-compete agreements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

and intangible assets were:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Amortization expense for
intangible assets was $6 million for the three months and $15
million for the nine months ended September&amp;#xA0;30, 2009. We
currently estimate amortization expense for each of the next five
years to be approximately $21 million or less.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

  <us-gaap:IncomeTaxDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0009_STD_p9m_20090930_0">&lt;div&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note&amp;#xA0;12.&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;Income Taxes:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;As of January&amp;#xA0;1, 2009,
our unrecognized tax benefits were $807 million. If we had
recognized all of these benefits, the net impact on our income tax
provision would have been $612 million. During the nine months
ended September&amp;#xA0;30, 2009, we recognized $173 million of
previously unrecognized tax benefits due to an agreement we reached
with the IRS on specific matters, settlements with various foreign
and state tax authorities, and the expiration of the statute of
limitations in various jurisdictions. In addition, unrecognized tax
benefits increased $110 million during the nine months ended
September&amp;#xA0;30, 2009 for additions based on current year tax
positions, prior year tax positions and adjustments for currency.
As a result, our net unrecognized tax benefits decreased $63
million during the nine months ended September&amp;#xA0;30, 2009. We
expect that the amount of unrecognized tax benefits will decrease
by&amp;#xA0;$60 million during the next 12 months due to various audit
settlements and the expiration of statutes of limitations. We
include accrued interest and penalties related to uncertain tax
positions in our tax provision. As of January&amp;#xA0;1, 2009, we had
$239 million of accrued interest and penalties. The decrease in
accrued interest and penalties during the nine months ended
September&amp;#xA0;30, 2009 was&amp;#xA0;$53 million.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We are regularly examined
by&amp;#xA0;various federal,&amp;#xA0;state and foreign tax authorities.
The U.S. federal statute of limitations remains open for the year
2000 and onward. Years 2000 through 2003&amp;#xA0;are currently under
examination by the IRS, and during the third quarter of 2009, we
reached an agreement with the IRS on specific matters relating to
those tax years. We expect the years under audit by the IRS to
close during 2010. We are also currently under examination by
taxing authorities in various U.S. state and foreign jurisdictions.
U.S. state and foreign jurisdictions have statutes of limitations
generally ranging from three to five years. Years still open to
examination by foreign tax authorities in major jurisdictions
include Germany (1999 onward), Brazil (2002 onward), Canada (2003
onward), Spain (2002 onward) and France (2006 onward).&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note
9.&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;Benefit Plans:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Pension
Plans&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Components of Net
Periodic Pension Cost:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Net periodic pension cost
consisted of the following for the three and nine months ended
September&amp;#xA0;30, 2009 and 2008:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;The following costs are
included within settlement losses above. Severance payments from
our cost savings initiatives and retired employees who elected
lump-sum payments resulted in settlement losses for our U.S. plans
of $15 million for the three months and $81 million for the nine
months ended September&amp;#xA0;30, 2009, and $20 million for the three
months and $41 million for the nine months ended September&amp;#xA0;30,
2008. Our non-U.S. plans also incurred a $1 million curtailment
charge in the third quarter of 2008 related to the split-off of the
&lt;i&gt;Post&lt;/i&gt; cereals business.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Employer
Contributions:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We make contributions to
our U.S. and non-U.S. pension plans, primarily to the extent that
they are tax deductible and do not generate an excise tax
liability. During the first nine months of 2009, we contributed
$225 million to our U.S. plans (including a $200 million
contribution made on May&amp;#xA0;1, 2009) and $124 million to our
non-U.S. plans. Based on current tax law, we plan to make further
contributions of approximately $15 million to our U.S. plans and
approximately $45 million to our non-U.S. plans during the
remainder of 2009. However, our actual contributions may differ due
to many factors, including changes in tax and other benefit laws,
or significant differences between expected and actual pension
asset performance or interest rates.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Postretirement Benefit
Plans&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Net postretirement health
care costs consisted of the following for the three and nine months
ended September&amp;#xA0;30, 2009 and 2008:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;The following costs are
included within other (credits) / costs above. We incurred
severance charges of $25 million during the second quarter of 2009
related to our Kraft Foods Europe Reorganization. We also reversed
$32 million in severance charges in the second quarter of 2009
related to our Restructuring Program as we sold a plant in Spain
that we previously announced we would close under the program.
Additionally, the postemployment cost of workforce reduction
initiatives announced under the Restructuring Program was $22
million during the three months and $145 million during the nine
months ended September&amp;#xA0;30, 2008.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" align="center" border="0"&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" colspan="17"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note
5.&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;Restructuring Costs:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;2004 &amp;#x2013; 2008
Restructuring Program:&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In 2008, we completed our
five-year restructuring program (the &amp;#x201C;Restructuring
Program&amp;#x201D;). The Restructuring Program&amp;#x2019;s objectives were
to leverage our global scale, realign and lower our cost structure,
and optimize capacity. As part of the Restructuring Program,
we:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 6px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px; MARGIN-LEFT: 4em; TEXT-INDENT: -1.5em"&gt;
&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&amp;#x2022;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;incurred $3.0
billion in pre-tax charges reflecting asset disposals, severance
and implementation costs;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px; MARGIN-LEFT: 4em; TEXT-INDENT: -1.5em"&gt;
&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&amp;#x2022;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;announced the
closure of 35 facilities and announced the elimination of
approximately 18,800 positions; and&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px; MARGIN-LEFT: 4em; TEXT-INDENT: -1.5em"&gt;
&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&amp;#x2022;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;will use cash to pay
for $2.0 billion of the $3.0 billion in charges.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;In the second quarter of
2009, we sold a plant in Spain that we previously announced we
would close under our Restructuring Program. Accordingly, we
reversed $35 million in Restructuring Program charges, primarily
related to severance, and recorded a $17 million loss on the
divestiture of the plant in the second quarter of 2009. The
reversal of the Restructuring Program costs, which affected the
segment operating income of the Kraft Foods Europe segment, was
recorded within asset impairment and exit costs. Since the
inception of the Restructuring Program, we have paid cash for $1.6
billion of the $2.0 billion in expected cash payments, including
$123 million paid in the first nine months of 2009. At
September&amp;#xA0;30, 2009, we had an accrual of $366 million, and we
had eliminated approximately 16,500 positions under the
Restructuring Program.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Restructuring liability
activity for the nine months ended September&amp;#xA0;30, 2009
was:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 1px"&gt;
&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;

&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Our 2009 activity was
related to the aforementioned reversal of $35 million and cash
outflows on prior year Restructuring Program charges. Our prior
year severance charges included the cost of benefits received by
terminated employees. Other prior year costs related primarily to
the renegotiation of supplier contract costs, workforce reductions
associated with facility closings and the termination of leasing
agreements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:RestructuringAndRelatedActivitiesDisclosureTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:RestructuringCostsAndAssetImpairmentCharges contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0009_STD_p9m_20090930_0" unitRef="USD" decimals="-6">9000000</us-gaap:RestructuringCostsAndAssetImpairmentCharges>
  <us-gaap:RestructuringSettlementAndImpairmentProvisions contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0009_STD_p9m_20090930_0" unitRef="USD" decimals="-6">-26000000</us-gaap:RestructuringSettlementAndImpairmentProvisions>
  <us-gaap:Revenues contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0009_STD_p9m_20090930_0" unitRef="USD" decimals="-6">29361000000</us-gaap:Revenues>
  <us-gaap:ScheduleOfSubsequentEventsTextBlock contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0009_STD_p9m_20090930_0">&lt;div&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note
15.&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;Subsequent Events:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;On September&amp;#xA0;7, 2009,
we disclosed that we approached the Board of Cadbury plc
(&amp;#x201C;Cadbury&amp;#x201D;) with a proposal to combine the two
companies. The Board of Cadbury has rejected this proposal. We
remain interested in working toward a recommended transaction. We
proposed an offer for Cadbury (the &amp;#x201C;Possible Offer&amp;#x201D;) of
300 pence in cash and 0.2589 new Kraft Foods shares per Cadbury
share. This valued each Cadbury share at 745 pence (based on the
closing price of $28.10 for a Kraft Foods share on
September&amp;#xA0;4, 2009 and an exchange rate of 1.6346 $/&amp;#xA3;) and
valued the entire issued share capital of Cadbury at &amp;#xA3;10.2
billion (approximately $16.7 billion). The combination would build
on Kraft Foods&amp;#x2019; position as a global powerhouse in snacks,
confectionery and quick meals with a rich portfolio of iconic
brands.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;The Possible Offer
contained several criteria, including our ability to obtain
satisfactory financing, that we would maintain an investment-grade
credit rating, and the right to change our offer at any
time.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Pursuant to the U.K. City
Code on Takeovers and Mergers, the U.K. Takeover Panel set a
deadline of November&amp;#xA0;9, 2009 for us to formally make an offer
for Cadbury, or walk away.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We evaluated subsequent
events through November&amp;#xA0;3, 2009 and included all accounting
and disclosure requirements related to subsequent events in our
financial statements.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/div&gt;</us-gaap:ScheduleOfSubsequentEventsTextBlock>
  <us-gaap:SegmentReportingDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="eol_PE71240---0910-Q0009_STD_p9m_20090930_0">&lt;div&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u&gt;Note
14.&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;Segment Reporting:&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Effective January 2009, we
began implementing changes to our operating structure based on our
&lt;i&gt;Organizing For Growth&lt;/i&gt; initiative and the Kraft Foods Europe
Reorganization. In line with our strategies, we are reorganizing
our European operations to function on a pan-European centralized
category management and value chain model, and we changed how we
work in Europe in two key ways:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;table style="BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" border="0"&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td width="5%"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" align="left" width="2%"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&amp;#x2022;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" width="1%"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" align="left"&gt;
&lt;p align="left"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We transitioned our European Biscuit, Chocolate, Coffee and
Cheese categories to fully integrated business units, further
strengthening our focus on these core categories. To ensure
decisions are made faster and closer to our customers and
consumers, each category is fully accountable for its financial
results, including marketing, manufacturing and R&amp;amp;D. Category
leadership, based in Zurich, Switzerland, reports to the Kraft
Foods Europe President. These business units now comprise the Kraft
Foods Europe segment.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;table style="BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" border="0"&gt;
&lt;tr&gt;
&lt;td width="5%"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" align="left" width="2%"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&amp;#x2022;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" width="1%"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top" align="left"&gt;
&lt;p align="left"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We aligned the reporting of our Central Europe operations into
our Kraft Foods Developing Markets segment to help build critical
scale in these countries. We operate a country-led model in these
markets.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;/tr&gt;
&lt;/table&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;We manufacture and market
packaged food products, including snacks, beverages, cheese,
convenient meals and various packaged grocery products. We manage
and report operating results through three commercial units: Kraft
Foods North America, Kraft Foods Europe and Kraft Foods Developing
Markets. We manage the operations of Kraft Foods North America and
Kraft Foods Europe by product category, and we manage the
operations of Kraft Foods Developing Markets by geographic
location. Our reportable segments are U.S. Beverages, U.S.
Cheese,&amp;#xA0;U.S. Convenient Meals, U.S. Grocery, U.S. Snacks,
Canada&amp;#xA0;&amp;amp; North America Foodservice, Kraft Foods Europe
(formerly known as European Union) and Kraft Foods Developing
Markets.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font size="1"&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Management uses segment
operating income to evaluate segment performance and allocate
resources. We believe it is appropriate to disclose this measure to
help investors analyze segment performance and trends. Segment
operating income excludes unrealized gains and losses on hedging
activities (which are a component of cost of sales), certain
components of our U.S. pension plan cost (which is a component of
cost of sales and marketing, administration and research costs),
general corporate expenses (which are a component of marketing,
administration and research costs) and amortization of intangibles
for all periods presented. In 2009, we began excluding certain
components of our U.S. pension plan cost from segment operating
income because we centrally manage pension plan funding decisions
and the determination of discount rate, expected rate of return on
plan assets and other actuarial assumptions. Therefore, we allocate
only the service cost component of our U.S. pension plan expense to
segment operating income. We exclude the unrealized gains and
losses on hedging activities from segment operating income in order
to provide better transparency of our segment operating results.
Once realized, the gains and losses on hedging activities are
recorded within segment operating results. Furthermore, we
centrally manage interest and other expense, net. Accordingly, we
do not present these items by segment because they are excluded
from the segment profitability measure that management
reviews.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Segment data
were:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;

&lt;td valign="top" colspan="18"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Asset Impairment Charges
&amp;#x2013;&lt;/i&gt; In the second quarter of 2009, we recorded a $9 million
asset impairment charge to write-off an investment in Norway. The
charge was recorded within asset impairment and exit costs within
the segment operating income of Kraft Foods Europe.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Unrealized Gains /
(Losses) on Hedging Activities&lt;/i&gt; &amp;#x2013; We recognized gains on
the change in unrealized hedging positions of $19 million for the
three months and $140 million for the nine months ended
September&amp;#xA0;30, 2009, and losses of $141 million for the three
months and $38 million for the nine months ended September&amp;#xA0;30,
2008.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;&lt;font style="FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman" size="2"&gt;Net revenues by consumer
sector, which includes &lt;i&gt;Kraft&lt;/i&gt; macaroni&amp;#xA0;and cheese
dinners in the Convenient Meals sector and the separation of
Canada&amp;#xA0;&amp;amp; N.A. Foodservice, and Kraft Foods Europe and
Kraft Foods Developing Markets into sector components,
were:&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 1px"&gt;
&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
&lt;/td&gt;
&lt;td valign="top"&gt;
&lt;p style="MARGIN-TOP: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 12px; MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px"&gt;
&lt;/p&gt;
